projectDesc.p: To the tune “Midnight Tune”—"Frozen clouds dim the sky" is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.rdg: To the tune “Midnight Tune”
Frozen clouds dim the sky,
a thin boat
departs the riverside on a whim,
crosses a thousand valleys and a thousand canyons,

into the depth of Yue streams
In Chinese folklore, this river is associated with a beautiful woman named Xi Shi, whose name has become synonymous with female beauty. According to the tale, she often washed her clothes in this river.,
Raging waves gradually die down,
A favorable wind suddenly rises.

Then I hear the traveling tradesmen calling to each other
A common way for tradesmen to communicate with each other at that time..
The lone sail hangs high;

On the painted bird
“鷁” is a legendary bird that was often painted on boats. It was believed to be a lucky charm for sailors because it could fly over water during storms. Here, “the painted bird” refers to the boat that the speaker is on.,
I swiftly pass the southern bank.
Before my eyes, the wine shop banner swings,
a small village wreathed in smoke,
and rows of frosty trees.
The setting sun retreats,

The fishermen strike the side of the boat
The fishermen strike the boat to give themselves a beat to sing along to. and return.
Withered lotuses fall apart,
Fading willows cover and reveal.
On the bank, in groups of two or three,

Girls are doing laundry
A typical scene for women at that time, but it could also be associated with the story of Xi Shi (see note above)..
Avoiding the travelers,
shy, they smile, chatting to each other.
Being here brings back my thoughts.

I have abandoned the embroidered chamber
Refers to a bedroom. It implies that the poet has left behind the wealthy, domestic life that he could otherwise have led..
Like a duckweed in the waves, I have nowhere to stay.
I sigh at the thought of reunion—
who can now believe in the earnest words that were said back then?
Wretched is the parting heart,

vainly regretting that the year has come to an end and the time to return home
In the Lunar calendar, the end of the year means the coming of Spring Festival, the most important festival for the reunion of families. has been delayed.
I let my watery eyes gaze
at the long, distant road to the capital.
The cry of the wild goose resounds, lingering in the vast evening sky.
